review.title: Phase Transitions and Backbones of the Asymmetric Traveling Salesman Problem
review.abstract: In recent years, there has been much interest in phase transitions of combinatorial problems. Phase transitions have been successfully used to analyze combinatorial optimization problems, characterize their typical-case features and locate the hardest problem instances. In this paper, we study phase transitions of the asymmetric Traveling Salesman Problem (ATSP), an NP-hard combinatorial optimization problem that has many real-world applications. Using random instances of up to 1,500 cities in which intercity distances are uniformly distributed, we empirically show that many properties of the problem, including the optimal tour cost and backbone size, experience sharp transitions as the precision of intercity distances increases across a critical value. Our experimental results on the costs of the ATSP tours and assignment problem agree with the theoretical result that the asymptotic cost of assignment problem is pi ^2 /6 the number of cities goes to infinity. In addition, we show that the average computational cost of the well-known branch-and-bound subtour elimination algorithm for the problem also exhibits a thrashing behavior, transitioning from easy to difficult as the distance precision increases. These results answer positively an open question regarding the existence of phase transitions in the ATSP, and provide guidance on how difficult ATSP problem instances should be generated.

sections.heading: 2. The Asymmetric Traveling Salesman Problem and Assignment Problem
sections.text: Given n cities and the distance or cost between individual cities, the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) is to find a minimum cost tour that each city visits once and returns to the starting city (Gutin & Punnen, 2002; Lawler et al., 1985). If the distance from the city i to the city j is the same as the distance from j to i, the problem is the symmetrical TSP (STSP). If the distance from the city i to the city is not necessarily equal to the reverse distance, the problem is the asymmetrical TSP (ATSP). The ATSP is more difficult than the STSP, in terms of optimization and approximation (Johnson et al., 2002). The TSPs are important NP-hard problems (Garey & Johnson, 1979; Karp, 1972) and have many practical applications.

sections.heading: 4.1 Phase Transitions in the ATSP
sections.text: We are particularly interested in possible phase transitions in ATSP costs, phase transitions in backbones, and phase transitions in the number of ATSP tours. Backbone results may shed some light on the intrinsic constraints between cities as the accuracy of distance measurement changes.

The reported tour costs are obtained by dividing the integer ATSP tour costs by n (R 1), where n is the number of cities and R is the range of intercity costs. sections.heading: 4.1.2 BACKBONE AND NUMBER OF OPTIMAL SOLUTIONS
sections.text: We now turn to the backbone of the ATSP, i.e. the percentage of directed arcs that occur in all optimal solutions; the backbone also exhibits phase transitions as the effective number of digits for distances increases; the result is contained in Figure 3 (a), where each data point averages over 10,000 problem cases; the reversed result is shown in Figure 3 (b), where the critical point = 1. Interestingly, the phase transition pattern of the backbone follows a similar trend to the percentage of different units in the distance matrix shown in Figure 1. Furthermore, the phase transition patterns of tour costs and backbones discussed in Section 4.3 are similar; the break of the backbone variables is related to the number of optimal solutions to a problem; we therefore examined the total number of optimal solutions in the ATSP, based on small ATSPs, as all optimal solutions to major problems are computationally too expensive.

sections.text: As a by-product of the phase transition results, we are now presenting numerical values of ATSP costs, AP costs and their accuracy asymptotically as the number of cities grows; we are trying to extend the theoretical results to AP costs, which approach asymptotically 2 = 6 (Aldous, 2001; Me ́ zard & Parsi, 1987); and the observations that the relative error of AP lower limits decreases as the problem size increases (Balas & Toth, 1985; Smith et al.). Not every real number can be represented in a digital computer, making it impossible to examine a theoretical result directly on the basis of a digital computer. For our purpose, the phase transition results suggest that the precision of intercity distances is high, all the quantity of intercity we have studied, including ATSP costs.

sections.heading: 6. Thrashing Behavior of Subtour Elimination
sections.text: All of the phase transition results discussed in the previous section indicate that the ATSP becomes more limited and difficult the higher the distance precision gets. In this section, we will examine how a known algorithm for the ATSP, the elimination of partial sections (Balas & Toth, 1985; Bellmore & Malone, 1971; Smith et al., 1977), behaves. We will separate this problem from the phase transition phenomena previously investigated because in this section we will look at the behavior of a particular algorithm that may not necessarily be a feature of the underlying problem. However, this remains a question of self-interest as this algorithm is the oldest and still one of the best-known methods for the ATSP, and we hope that a better understanding of an efficient algorithm for the ATSP can shed light on the typical computational complexity of the problem.

sections.heading: 7. Related Work and Discussions
sections.text: The first line of related work was on the expected complexity of tree search, which sheds light on the BnB subtour elimination algorithms described in Section 6.1 on how to solve the ATSP problem in a tree search, but the analysis was done on an abstract random tree model called an incremental tree T. T (Karp & Pearl, 1983; McDiarmid, 1990; McDiarmid & Provan, 1991; Zhang & Korf, 1995; Zhang, 1999) T's internal nodes have a variable number of children and edges in T. The cost of a node in T is the sum of marginal costs along the path from the root to that node. An optimal target node is a knot-knot-knot-knot-knot minimum cost at a fixed depth. The general goal is to find an optimal target node transition at the cost of the optimal target node.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions
sections.text: Our main contributions to this research are twofold: First, we responded positively to the long-standing question of whether the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) has phase transitions (Kirkpatrick & Toulouse, 1985) and disapproved of the belief that the problem does not have phase transitions (Kirkpatrick & Selman, 1994); we investigated this problem on a more general, optimistic version of the problem, the asymmetric TSP (ATSP); we empirically demonstrated that random problem transitions with distances from a uniform distribution; that many important properties, including ATSP tour costs and the break of backbone variables, have two characteristically different values; and the transitions between them are rather abrupt and dramatic, with the control parameters of phase transitions between phase transitions being.

The Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) (Gutin & Punnen, 2002; Lawler, Lenstra, Kan, & Shmoys, 1985) is an archetypical combinatorial optimization problem and one of the first NP-hard problems studied (Karp, 1972).

Therefore, phase transitions have been used to help generate the hardest problem instances for testing and comparing algorithms for decision problems (Achlioptas, Gomes, Kautz, & Selman, 2000; Cheeseman et al., 1991; Mitchell et al., 1992). Another important and useful concept for characterizing combinatorial problems is that of the backbone (Kirkpatrick & Toulouse, 1985; Monasson et al., 1999). A backbone variable refers to a variable that has a fixed value among all optimal solutions of a problem; and all such backbone variables are collectively referred to as the backbone of the problem. If a problem has a backbone variable, an algorithm will not find a solution to the problem until the backbone variable is set to its correct value. Therefore, the fraction of backbone variables, the percentage of variables being in the backbone, reflects the constrainedness of the problem and directly affects an algorithm searching for a solution. The larger a backbone, the more tightly constrained the problem becomes. As a result it is more likely for an algorithm to set a backbone variable to a wrong value, which may consequently require a large amount of computation to recover from such a mistake. However, the research on the phase transitions and (particularly) backbones of optimization problems is limited, which is in sharp contrast with the numerous studies of the phase transitions and backbones of decision problems, represented by Boolean satisfiability (e.g., Cheeseman et al., 1991; Mitchell et al., 1992; Hogg, 1995; Selman & Kirkpatrick, 1996; Monasson et al., 1999). An early work on the symmetric TSP introduced the concept of backbones (Kirkpatrick & Toulouse, 1985). However, it has left the question whether there exists a phase transition of the TSP, the optimization version of the problem to be specific, open since 1985. If the cost of a leaf node is less than the current upper bound , is revised to the cost of x. If x’s AP solution is not a complete tour and its cost is greater than or equal to , x is pruned, because node costs are monotonic so that no descendant of x will have a cost smaller than x’s cost. Otherwise, x is expanded, generating all its child nodes. To find an optimal goal node quickly, the children of x should be searched in an increasing order of their costs. In other words we use node ordering to reduce the number of nodes explored. The analysis was carried out on an abstract random tree model called incremental tree T (Karp & Pearl, 1983; McDiarmid, 1990; McDiarmid & Provan, 1991; Zhang & Korf, 1995; Zhang, 1999). The internal nodes of T has variable number of children and edges in T are assigned finite and nonnegative random values. The cost of a node in T is the sum of the edge costs along the path from the root to that node. An optimal goal node is a node of minimum cost at a fixed depth d. The overall goal is to find an optimal goal node. There exist phase transitions in the cost of the optimal goal node and the complexity to the problem of finding an optimal goal in T . The control parameter is the expected number of child nodes of a common parent node which have the same cost as the parent. The cost of an optimal goal node almost surely undergoes a phase transition from a linear function of depth d to a constant when the expected same-cost children of a node increases beyond one. Meanwhile, best-first search and depth-first branch-and-bound also exhibit a phase-transition behavior, i.e., their expected complexity changes dramatically from exponential to polynomial in d as the expected same-cost children of a node is reduced to below one. Note that following the result by Dechter & Pearl (1985), best-first search is optimal for searching this random tree among all algorithms using the same cost function, in terms of number of node expansions, up to tie breaking.

metadata.abstractText: In recent years, there has been much interest in phase transitions of combinatorial problems. Phase transitions have been successfully used to analyze combinatorial optimization problems, characterize their typical-case features and locate the hardest problem instances. In this paper, we study phase transitions of the asymmetric Traveling Salesman Problem (ATSP), an NP-hard combinatorial optimization problem that has many real-world applications. Using random instances of up to 1,500 cities in which intercity distances are uniformly distributed, we empirically show that many properties of the problem, including the optimal tour cost and backbone size, experience sharp transitions as the precision of intercity distances increases across a critical value. Our experimental results on the costs of the ATSP tours and assignment problem agree with the theoretical result that the asymptotic cost of assignment problem is 2=6 as the number of cities goes to infinity. In addition, we show that the average computational cost of the well-known branch-and-bound subtour elimination algorithm for the problem also exhibits a thrashing behavior, transitioning from easy to difficult as the distance precision increases. These results answer positively an open question regarding the existence of phase transitions in the ATSP, and provide guidance on how difficult ATSP problem instances should be generated.
